name: Acorn Barnacle
fun_fact: They have the longest penises relative to body size in the animal kingdom, six times their body length.
distribution: Cold temperate to sub-polar latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere
taxonomy: Subphylum Crustacea (crabs, shrimps, and relatives), Order Sessilia (acorn barnacles)

name: American Horseshoe Crab
fun_fact: They more closely related to spiders and scorpions than crabs, has blue copper-based blood used in medical tests.
distribution: North America along the Atlantic and gulf coasts from Maine to Mexico
ecosystem: Beaches and other soft bottom habitats
taxonomy: Phylum Arthropoda (arthropods), Family Limulidae (horseshoe crabs)

name: American Lobster
fun_fact: They are the largest crustaceans in the world by weight, with the heaviest recorded individual weighing 44 pounds (20 kg).
distribution: Restricted to temperate latitudes of the Northwestern Atlantic Ocean from North Carolina to Labrador
taxonomy: Subphylum Crustacea (crabs, shrimps, and relatives), Family Nephropidae (clawed lobsters)

name: American Oyster
fun_fact: Each of them can filter approximately 50 gallons of water per day, helping to keep their surrounding waters clean.
distribution: Sub-tropical to temperate latitudes of the western Atlantic Ocean
taxonomy: Class Bivalvia (clams, oysters, and relatives), Family Ostreidae (true oysters)

name: Antarctic Krill
fun_fact: Antarctic krill have a combined biomass greater than that of all humans on Earth.
distribution: Circumpolar in the Southern Hemisphere
taxonomy: Subphylum Crustacea (crabs, shrimps, and relatives), Family Euphausidae (krill)

name: Argentine Shortfin Squid
fun_fact: The fishing lights used to capture this species are so bright that they can be seen from outer space.
distribution: Subtropical to subpolar latitudes off Brazil and Argentina
taxonomy: Class Cephalopoda (octopuses, squids, calmars, and relatives), Family Ommastrephidae

name: Blue Glaucus
fun_fact: The Blue Glaucus preys on venomous organisms like the Portuguese man o' war and stores their venom for its own defense.
distribution: Temperate and tropical waters worldwide
taxonomy: Subphylum Crustacea (crabs, shrimps, and relatives), Order Sessilia (acorn barnacles)

name: Bluebottle
fun_fact: Despite their name, bluebottles are not true jellyfish but are a type of colonial organism called a siphonophore.
distribution: Indo-Pacific waters
taxonomy: Class Hydrozoa (hydrozoans), Order Siphonophora (siphonophores), Family Physaliidae (men o’ war)

name: Chilean Basket Star
fun_fact: Its arms can branch out many times, resembling a basket, which helps it catch food particles in the water.
distribution: Sub-polar to polar latitudes of South America
taxonomy: Class Ophiuroidea (brittle stars), Suborder Euryalina (basket stars)

name: Christmas Tree Worm
fun_fact: Named for their colorful, spiraled appearance, these worms quickly retract into their tubes when threatened.
distribution: Tropics
taxonomy: Phylum Annelid (ringed worms), Family Serpulidae (tube building worms)

name: Cockscomb Cup Coral
fun_fact: Unlike most corals, it can live in cold, deep-sea environments.
distribution: Tropical to sub-polar latitudes in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans
taxonomy: Class Anthozoa (corals, anemones, and relatives), Order Scleractinia (stony corals)

name: Crown-of-thorns Starfish
fun_fact: This starfish has venomous spines and is notorious for preying on coral, which can devastate coral reefs.
distribution: Tropical Pacific and Indian oceans
taxonomy: Class Asteroidea (sea stars), Family Acanthasteridae (crown-of-thorns sea stars)

name: Bearded Seal
fun_fact: Named for its whiskers, which it uses to feel for food on the ocean floor.
distribution: Northern Hemisphere, Arctic Ocean and Alaska
ecosystem: Feed in ocean; breed, mate and rest on sea ice
taxonomy: Order Carnivora, Family Phocidae

name: Beluga Whale
fun_fact: Known as the  'canaries of the sea' for their wide range of vocal sounds.
distribution: Restricted to subpolar and polar waters above the Arctic Circle
ecosystem: Shallow, coastal waters and near the ice edge; sometimes in rivers
taxonomy: Suborder Odontoceti (toothed whales), Family Monodontidae (white whales)

name: Blue Whale
fun_fact: The largest animal on Earth, its heart is the size of a small car!
distribution: Worldwide in tropical to polar latitudes
taxonomy: Suborder Mysticeti (baleen whales), Family Balaenopteridae (rorquals)

name: Bowhead Whale
fun_fact: Can live over 200 years, making it one of the longest-living mammals.
distribution: Northern Hemisphere, Arctic Ocean
taxonomy: Order Cetartiodactyla, Family Balaenidae (Right whales)

name: California Sea Lion
fun_fact: These playful animals are often seen 'surfing' the waves near shorelines.
distribution: Eastern Pacific Ocean along North America coast
taxonomy: Class Mammalia (mammals), Order Carnivora (carnivores), Family Otariidae (eared seals)

name: Common Bottlenose Dolphin
fun_fact: Known for their intelligence, they are frequently seen riding the bow waves of boats.
distribution: Worldwide in tropical to subpolar latitudes
taxonomy: Order Cetacea (whales and dolphins), Family Delphinidae (dolphins)

name: Banded Sea Krait
fun_fact: Although highly venomous, it rarely bites humans and spends much of its life in the water.
distribution: Tropical to warm temperate latitudes in the eastern Indian and western Pacific oceans
taxonomy: Order Squamata (snakes and lizards), Family Elapidae (sea snakes and relatives)

name: Flatback Turtle
fun_fact: The only sea turtle species that nests solely in Australia.
distribution: Coastal waters of Australia and Papua New Guinea
ecosystem: Seagrass beds and other coastal habitats
taxonomy: Order Testudines (turtles, tortoises and terrapins), Family Cheloniidae (hard shelled sea turtles)

name: Green Turtle
fun_fact: Gets its name from the greenish color of its fat, caused by its herbivorous diet.
distribution: Worldwide in tropical to temperate latitudes
taxonomy: Order Testudines (turtles, tortoises and terrapins), Family Cheloniidae (hard-shelled sea turtles)

name: Hawksbill Turtle
fun_fact: Named for its beak-like mouth, it is known for its beautiful shell, which was once heavily poached.
distribution: Worldwide in tropical to temperate latitudes
taxonomy: Order Testudines (turtles, tortoises and terrapins), Family Cheloniidae (hard shelled sea turtles)

name: Kemp’s Ridley Turtle
fun_fact: Known for its synchronized mass nesting called 'arribada', where thousands of females come ashore to lay eggs.
distribution: Gulf of Mexico, U.S. Atlantic seaboard and parts of the Mediterranean
taxonomy: Order Testudines (turtles, tortoises and terrapins), Family Cheloniidae (hard shelled sea turtles)

name: Leatherback Turtle
fun_fact: The largest of all sea turtles, it can dive deeper than any other turtle species.
distribution: Worldwide in tropical to sub-arctic latitudes
ecosystem: Coastal to open ocean; deep diver
taxonomy: Order Testudines (turtles, tortoises and terrapins), Family Dermochelyidae (leatherback sea turtles)

name: Beach
fun_fact: Beaches naturally shift and change over time due to wind, waves, and currents.
distribution: Worldwide in all latitudes

name: Coral Reef
fun_fact: Coral reefs are often called the 'rainforests of the sea' due to their rich biodiversity.
distribution: Worldwide in tropical latitudes

name: Deep Hydrothermal Vent
fun_fact: These vents are home to unique species that thrive in extreme conditions, with some bacteria deriving energy from chemicals instead of sunlight.
distribution: Worldwide at the edges of tectonic plates

name: Fjord
fun_fact: Fjords were carved by glaciers during the Ice Ages and can reach depths of over 1,000 meters.
distribution: Cold temperate to polar latitudes of the north Atlantic, north Pacific, and south Pacific oceans

name: Ice Edge
fun_fact: The ice edge is a critical habitat for polar bears, seals, and seabirds, as it offers rich feeding grounds.
distribution: Arctic and Antarctic polar waters

name: Kelp Forest
fun_fact: Kelp can grow up to 60 cm (24 inches) per day, making it one of the fastest-growing organisms on Earth.
distribution: Worldwide in temperate to polar latitudes

name: Atlantic Bluefin Tuna
fun_fact: Known for its speed, it can reach over 40 miles per hour when hunting.
distribution: Sub-tropical to cold temperate latitudes of the Atlantic Ocean
taxonomy: Order Scombriformes (mackerels and relatives), Family Scombridae (mackerels and tunas)

name: Atlantic Cod
fun_fact: Once so abundant, it was a staple food for centuries, leading to the term 'codfish aristocracy.'
distribution: Temperate to sub-polar latitudes of the north Atlantic Ocean
taxonomy: Order Gadiformes (cods and relatives), Family Gadidae (cods)

name: Atlantic Goliath Grouper
fun_fact: This massive fish can grow up to 800 pounds and make deep booming sounds.
distribution: Tropical to temperate latitudes in the Atlantic Ocean
ecosystem: Coral reefs and other hard bottoms as well as mangrove forests
taxonomy: Order Perciformes (perch-like fishes), Family Epinephelidae (groupers and relatives)

name: Atlantic Salmon
fun_fact: Famous for their epic migrations, they can leap up waterfalls to reach their spawning grounds.
distribution: Temperate to sub-polar latitudes of the north Atlantic Ocean
taxonomy: Order Salmoniformes (salmons and relatives), Family Salmonidae (trouts and salmons)

name: Atlantic Trumpetfish
fun_fact: This fish often hides among sea fans or other vertical structures, mimicking their movements to avoid predators.
distribution: Tropical western Atlantic Ocean from Florida (and Bermuda) to Brazil, including the Gulf of Mexico
ecosystem: Coral and rocky reefs and nearby seagrass beds; often hide among soft corals
taxonomy: Order Syngnathiformes (pipefishes and relatives), Family Aulostomidae (trumpetfishes)

name: Atlantic Wolffish
fun_fact: Its powerful jaws can crush crabs and sea urchins, and its antifreeze proteins keep its blood flowing in icy waters.
distribution: Cold temperate to subpolar north Atlantic Ocean
taxonomy: Order Cottiformes (sculpins and relatives), Family Anarhichadidae (wolffishes)

name: Adelie Penguin
fun_fact: These penguins build their nests out of stones and are known to steal stones from their neighbors.
distribution: Circumpolar around Antarctica
ecosystem: Nest on cobble beaches; feed in Antarctic currents
taxonomy: Order Sphenisciformes (penguins), Family Spheniscidae (penguins)

name: Artic Tern
fun_fact: Known for the longest migration of any bird, traveling from the Arctic to the Antarctic and back each year.
distribution: Worldwide
ecosystem: Nest along coasts; feed in coastal to open ocean (pelagic) waters
taxonomy: Order Charadriiformes (gulls, auks, and relatives), Family Sternidae (terns)

name: Atlantic Puffin
fun_fact: Often called 'sea parrots' due to their colorful beaks, they can carry multiple fish in their beaks at once to feed their chicks.
distribution: Cold temperate to polar latitudes of the north Atlantic and Arctic oceans
ecosystem: Nest in coastal grasses; feed in coastal to open ocean (pelagic) waters
taxonomy: Order Charadriiformes (gulls, auks, and relatives), Family Alcidae (auks)

name: Bald Eagle
fun_fact: Though not actually bald, its white head contrasts sharply with its dark body, giving it a 'bald' appearance.
distribution: Sub-tropical to sub-polar latitudes of North America
ecosystem: Nest in treetops; feed in freshwater and coastal waters
taxonomy: Order Accipitriformes (raptors and relatives), Family Accipitridae (eagles, hawks, and relatives)

name: Blue-footed Booby
fun_fact: Famous for their bright blue feet, which they show off in elaborate mating dances.
distribution: Tropical latitudes of the eastern Pacific Ocean
ecosystem: Nest on rocky shores; feed in coastal to open ocean (pelagic) waters
taxonomy: Order Pelecaniformes (pelicans, boobies, and relatives), Family Sulidae (boobies)

name: Brown Pelican
fun_fact: Brown pelicans catch their prey by plunge diving, but they can't fly or swim well until they expel all the water they gulp along with their catch!
distribution: Tropical to cold temperate latitudes of North and South America
ecosystem: Nest in mangrove forests and on small islands; feed in coastal to open ocean (pelagic) waters
taxonomy: Order Pelecaniformes (pelicans, boobies, and relatives), Family Pelecanidae (pelicans)

name: Barndoor Skate
fun_fact: Famous for their bright blue feet, which they show off in elaborate mating dances.
distribution: Temperate latitudes of the northwest Atlantic Ocean
taxonomy: Order Rajiformes (skates and relatives), Family Rajidae (skates)

name: Basking Shark
fun_fact: Basking sharks have been observed leaping out of the water, which may be a way of getting rid of parasites.
distribution: Worldwide in warm to cold temperate latitudes; absent from the tropics
taxonomy: Order Lamniformes (mackerel sharks and relatives), Family Cetorhinidae (basking sharks)

name: Blacktip Shark
fun_fact: Blacktip sharks have specialized cells in their snouts called electroreceptors that allow them to detect the electric current of nearby prey.
distribution: Worldwide in tropical to warm temperate waters
taxonomy: Class Chondrichthyes, Order Carcharhiniforms (ground sharks), Family Carcharhinidae (requiem sharks)

name: Blue Shark
fun_fact: They are one of the fastest sharks in the world, using their speed to hunt prey like sardines and squid.
distribution: Worldwide in tropical to cold temperate latitudes
taxonomy: Order Carcharhiniformes (ground sharks), Family Carcharhinidae (requiem sharks)

name: Blue Spotted Ribbontail Ray
fun_fact: They use their striking blue spots as a warning to predators to stay away
distribution: Indo-Pacific Ocean
taxonomy: Class Chondrichthyes (cartilaginous fishes) Order Myliobatiformes (stingrays)

name: Bull Shark
fun_fact: They can survive in both saltwater and freshwater, making them one of the few shark species that can travel far up rivers and even inhabit lakes
distribution: Worldwide in tropical to warm temperate latitudes
ecosystem: Coastal seas and slow moving, coastal rivers (freshwater)
taxonomy: Order Carcharhiniformes (groundsharks), Family Carcharhinidae (requiem sharks)
